p: Type I interferons (IFN-I) are members from a large family of signaling proteins known for their potent antiviral activity. IFN-I were discovered in 1957 by Lindenmann and Isaacs and received their names based on the ability to interfere with influenza virus replication in chick cell culture [ 1â€“ 3]. In recent years, the knowledge about the mechanism of IFN-I production has quickly expanded.
